instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP0V9_SSD: What is PP0V9_SSD? PP0V9_SSD is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on Macbooks with soldered on storage and must be present for the SSD to show up. .
definitions.PP2V7_NAND: What is PP2V7_NAND? PP2V7_NAND is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on Macbooks with soldered on storage and must be present for the SSD to show up. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V, 0.2667A
threads.message:
Hi. I need help, please.
The customer stated that it suddenly stop to0 turn on.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.63V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 0.79V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.19V
<SIGNAL>PMU_PVDDMAIN_EN</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>P3V3MAIN_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> = 3.28V
<SIGNAL>PCH_RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.0V
<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN</SIGNAL> = 0 V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> = 0

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0v

<SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>SSD0_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 0V

After all measurements, I found out that the battery was flat and maybe dead. 
The battery was replaced and now it turns on, but it is still stuck in 5v (not charging) and after a few secs my amp meter goes off (charger enters in protection mode).
So, now it turns on only if a charged battery is connected, but the battery is not charging and the voltage is stuck on 5v, but mac is still on.
Please any advice
Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V, 0.2667A
threads.message:
Stays on and working?
Tried DFU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V, 0.2667A
threads.message:
Yes, stays on and working.
But doesn't charge the battery.
The amp meter shows 5v, 0.2667A just when there is no battery.
After connecting, the battery mac turns on and works fine, but the amp meter stays off.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V, 0.2667A
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V, 0.2667A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.23V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL> - 1.8V

The other mac does not recognize the faulty mac when in DFU mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V, 0.2667A
threads.message:
Isn't there more than one <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip?

"<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0V"
1V1 LDO should appear on the powered port only.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V, 0.2667A
